[[Centaurus]] [[45th parallel north|45]] [[South Pole|90]] April Antlia(IPAc-enˈæntliə; fromAncient Greek) is aconstellationin the southern sky. Its name means "pump" and it specifically represents an air pump. The constellation was created in the 18th century from an undesignated region of sky, so the stars comprising Antlia are faint. The brightest star isAlpha Antliaeis an orangegiant stargiantthat is a suspectedvariable star, ranging betweenapparent magnitudes4.22 and 4.29.NGC 2997, aspiral galaxy, and theAntlia DwarfAntlia Dwarf Galaxylie within Antlia's borders.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:Antlia bode.JPGthumbborder300pxleftJohann Bode's depiction of Antlia.The French astronomerNicolas Louis de Lacaillefirst described the constellation in French asla Machine Pneumatique(the Pneumatic Pump) in 175152,cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/lacaille.htmLacaille’s Southern Planisphere of 1756Star Tales[[Ian Ridpath|Ridpath, Ian]]Self-published25 August 2015cite journalLacaille, Nicolas Louis1756Relation abrégée du Voyage fait par ordre du Roi au cap de Bonne-espéranceMémoires de l'Académie Royale des Sciences519–592 [589]http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k35505/f787Frenchcommemorating theair pumpinvented by the French physicistDenis Papin.cite webRidpathIanStar TalesAntliahttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/antlia.htm3 December 2007noHe had observed and catalogued almost 10,000 southern stars during a two-year stay at theCape of Good Hope, devising fourteen new constellations in uncharted regions of theSouthern Celestial Hemispherenot visible from Europe. All but one honoured instruments that symbolised theAge of Enlightenment.efnThe exception is [[Mensa (constellation)|Mensa]], named for the [[Table Mountain]]. The other thirteen (alongside Antlia) are [[Caelum]], [[Circinus]], [[Fornax]], [[Horologium (constellation)|Horologium]], [[Microscopium]], [[Norma (constellation)|Norma]], [[Octans]], [[Pictor]], [[Pyxis]], [[Reticulum]], [[Sculptor (constellation)|Sculptor]] and [[Telescopium]].{{sfn|Wagman|2003|ppsfnWagman20035-6Lacaille Latinised the name toAntlia pneumaticaon his 1763 chart. John Herschel proposed shrinking the name to one word, which was universally taken up.sfnWagman200325

Though Antlia was technically visible to ancient Greek astronomers, its stars were too faint to have been included in any constellations.Because of this, its main stars have no particular pattern and it is devoid of bright deep-sky objects.Lacaille andJohann Bodeeach depicted Antlia differently, as either the single-cylinder vacuum pump used in Papin's initial experiments, or the more advanced double-cylinder version.TheInternational Astronomical Unionsubsequently adopted it as one of the 88 modern constellations. There is no mythology attached to Antlia as Lacaille discontinued the tradition of giving names from mythology to constellations and instead chose names mostly from scientific instruments.

According to some, the most prominent stars that now comprise Antlia were once included within the ancient constellationArgo Navis, the Ship of the Argonauts, which due to its immense size was split into several smaller constellations by Lacaille in 1763.Peter Birren (2002) Objects in the Heavens, pp. 9, 45 (ISBN 155369662X).Thomas William Webb (Dover Publications 1962) Celestial objects for common telescopes, Volume 2, p. 36.However, given the faintness and obscurity of its stars, most authorities do not believe that the ancient Greeks included Antlia as part of their classical depiction of Argo Navis.Ian Ridpath (2002) Stars and Planets, pp, 65, 122. (ISBN 0-7894-8988-0)
article.heading: In non-Western astronomy
article.paragraph: Chinese astronomers were able to view what is modern Antlia from their latitudes, and incorporated its stars into two different constellations. Several stars in the southern part of Antlia were a portion of "Dong'ou", which represented an area in southern China.Furthermore,Epsilon AntliaeEpsilon,Eta AntliaeEta, andTheta Antliaewere incorporated into the celestial temple, which also contained stars from modernPyxis.
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Covering 238.9 square degrees and hence 0.579% of the sky, Antlia ranks 62nd of the88 modern constellationsby area.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htmConstellations: Andromeda–IndusStar Tales[[Ian Ridpath|Ridpath, Ian]]self-published26 August 2015Its position in theSouthern Celestial Hemispheremeans that the wholeconstellationis visible to observers south of 49N.efnWhile parts of the constellation technically rise above the horizon to observers between the 49°N and 65°N, stars within a few degrees of the horizon are to all intents and purposes unobservable.<ref nameIt is bordered byHydra (constellation)Hydrathe sea snake to the north,Pyxisthe compass to the west,Vela (constellation)Velathe sails to the south, andCentaurusthe centaur to the east. This group of constellations is prominent in the southern sky in late winter and spring. The three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is 'Ant'.cite journalRussellHenry NorrisHenry Norris RussellThe New International Symbols for the Constellations[[Popular Astronomy (US magazine)|Popular Astronomy]]304691922PA.....30..469R1922The official constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of twelve segments (illustrated in infobox). In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA0926.5andRA1105.6, while thedeclinationcoordinates are between -24.54 and -40.42.Cite journalAntlia, Constellation BoundaryThe ConstellationsInternational Astronomical Unionhttp://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#ant26 August 2015

article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: File:NGC 2997 ESO.jpgthumbborderleft300pxA composite image of NGC 2997.Because it occupies a part of thecelestial spherethat faces away from theMilky Way, Antlia contains very few deep-sky objects. It contains noglobular clusters, noplanetary nebulae, and noopen clusters. However, it does contain several galaxies.

NGC 2997is a loose face-onspiral galaxyof typeGalaxy morphological classificationSc.It is the brightest galaxy in Antlia at an integrated magnitude of 10.6.Though nondescript in most amateur telescopes, it presents bright clusters of young stars and many dark dust lanes in photographs.

TheAntlia Dwarf, a 14.8mdwarf spheroidal galaxythat belongs to ourLocal Groupof galaxies. It was discovered only as recently as 1997.cite webhttp://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/ap970423.htmlAntlia: A New Galactic Neighbor9 April 201223 April 1997Astronomy Picture of the DayNemiroffRobert
